title: Black Friday 2021 cycling deals | The best bike bargains so far
content:
Black Friday 2021 is here! This is your chance to save on a wide range of cycling products, from clothing to smart trainers, Garmin computers to tyres. Here is BikeRadar’s selection of the best Black Friday cycling deals we’ve found.

GoPros, helmets, GPS computers and more are all here. You might be looking for cycling gifts in the run-up to Christmas, or perhaps you just want to treat yourself (you deserve it after all) – either way, Black Friday’s the time to nab a bargain.

In this article, we’ve picked out the best cycling deals available for Black Friday 2021. We’ll keep this page up-to-date with the best offers throughout the day.

Where to find the best Black Friday cycling deals

Black Friday is here! Take a look below for a run-down of which retailers and brands have launched the best Black Friday sales.

Black Friday cycling deals: quick links

  • Amazon – The retail giant’s ‘Black Friday Week’ sale runs until 26 November
  • Wiggle – The Wiggle ‘Brighter Black Friday’ includes up to 50% off cycling shoes, wheels and tyres, and cycling clothing
  • ProBikeKit – Big Black Friday savings in the UK and US
  • Halfords – A wide range of Black Friday deals online, including discounts on nearly 100 cycling products
  • Tredz – ‘Black Ticket’ event with significant discounts on ‘nearly new’ ex-demo and ex-display bikes. Spend and save up to £300
  • Sigma Sports – Save up to 40% on a wide range of products, including clothing, helmets, smart trainers and cycling shoes
  • Competitive Cyclist – Save big over ‘Black Weekend’ if you’re in the US
  • Chain Reaction Cycles – New Black Friday deals released
  • Currys – the store’s Black Friday sale is underway
  • eBay – Reductions galore in the auction site’s Black Friday sale

Scroll further down and you’ll see we’ve also answered a few key questions about Black Friday.

And make sure you check out our round-ups to the best Black Friday Garmin deals, as well as the best Black Friday GoPro deals and best Black Friday bike light deals.

What is Black Friday?

Traditionally taking place the day after Thanksgiving, Black Friday has been going on for decades in the US. It’s become more popular lately in the UK, getting bigger and lasting longer each year

Further down this page, we’ll also delve into Cyber Monday and how it’s different from Black Friday.

When is Black Friday 2021?

Andy Lloyd / Immediate Media

Black Friday 2021 takes place on 26 November, but it no longer lasts for a single day. Rather, the discounting continues for at least a fortnight. In recent years, some retailers even unveiled early-bird ‘pre-Black Friday’ sales in mid-November.

As many studies have now shown, Black Friday Deals aren’t always as spectacular as they might appear to be. Historic price comparison tools such as CamelCamelCamel are well worth using to ensure you aren’t getting caught up in the hype.

That said, there are usually a few gems tucked away in the dusty corners of each retailer’s site, and you can rely on BikeRadar to do the digging and find these for you.

How to get a good deal on Black Friday 2021

  • A little research goes a long way. Read a few online reviews before you commit to buy. There may be a reason for that 40 per cent discount
  • Have you actually thought about what you want to buy? We recommend you put together a wishlist in advance so you don’t come to regret a rash decision
  • Take price drops with a pinch of salt: they can often be hugely exaggerated, since they’re listed against an RRP that might be years old. Luckily, we track deal prices and do our best to let you know about a product’s price history so you know you’re definitely getting the best deal
  • Don’t let the stress get to you! If you see a deal that’s marked as ‘nearly out of stock’, add it to your shopping basket straight away. Then take a look at the prices that other retailers are advertising. You normally get at least a couple of minutes before the item leaves your basket.

Should I wait for Cyber Monday?

Jack Luke / Immediate Media

What used to be the online-exclusive sequel to Black Friday, Cyber Monday is becoming obsolete. We make an ever greater proportion of purchases on the web than in brick-and-mortar shops. Retailers now seldom offer deals either just in-store or online.

However, the absence of Covid restrictions in the UK this year will inevitably lead to more shop tills ringing than in last winter’s lockdown. Perhaps physical stores will keep back some deals for Cyber Monday.

What does this mean for you? Expect a hectic four-day period of sales from 26 to 29 November and, if you see a barnstorming bargain on Black Friday, we don’t advise hanging on for the price to drop on Cyber Monday.
